Withdrawals by the owner are recorded in the______ account.

questiontext.text: Choose the most appropriate alternative from the options provided.

generalfeedback.text:
An asset is a resource to the business.

Income will increase owners equity.

questiontext.text: Choose the most appropriate alternative from the options provided.

generalfeedback.text: Inventory is a current asset. A 10-year building loan is a long-term liability. A factory building is a fixed asset. A creditor is a current liability.

questiontext.text: Choose the most appropriate alternative from the options provided.

generalfeedback.text: A delivery vehicle is an asset. Advertising costs incurred is an expense. A loan from an investor is a liability. Interest earned is income.

questiontext.text: In activity-based costing what is meant by the term 'cost driver'?

generalfeedback.text:
Option 3 is correct.

A cost driver is an activity that causes a cost to be incurred. The more complex the operations, the more cost-driving activities are likely to exist.

answer.text: A cost driver is someone who operates the machinery in the factory.
A cost driver refers to a direct cost in the manufacturing process.
A cost driver is an activity that causes a cost to be incurred.

questiontext.text: Which of the following would be a relevant cost driver to select for the overhead "set-ups"?

When disposing of an asset one would remove the accumulated depreciation from the books by debiting the accumulated depreciation account.

Which contra account is credited?

generalfeedback.text:
Option is 3 correct.

The asset disposal account is credited with the total accumulated depreciation amount.

answer.text: The account of the asset that was sold.

questiontext.text: Which of the following accounting entries should not appear in the account 'Asset Disposal' on the sale of a non-current asset?

generalfeedback.text:
Option is 1 correct.

There would be no single Carrying Value entry. This is calculated using the double entry system of recording the Cost Price and the Accumulated Depreciation amount.

questiontext.text: Which of the following are mandatory disclosures in the financials of the close corporation?

generalfeedback.text:
All options are correct.

The Act requires that the annual financial statements must disclose separately the aggregate amounts as at the end of the financial year, of each of the following:
• contributions by members,
• retained earnings,
• revaluations of property, plant and equipment (forming part of ‘other components of equity’)
• amounts of loans to members, and
• amounts of loans from members

questiontext.text:
A company has an independent estate broker provide an evaluation on the company's building. The estate broker has reported an increase in value of R200 000.

Would this revaluation surplus be included in the income statement or in the statement of conprehensive income in the financials of the company?

generalfeedback.text:
Option 1 is correct.
The revaluation surplus would not be included in the general profit and loss items on the income statement. It should be reflected separately in the statement of comprehensive income as it reflects a change in equity.

questiontext.text: Which account holds the depreciation amounts of an asset until it is written off?

generalfeedback.text:
Option 1 is correct.

The accumulated depreciation account is also called the provision of depreciation account. It holds the depreciation amounts of an asset until it is written off, sold or scrapped.

questiontext.text: Which type of account is Purchases?

generalfeedback.text:
Statement 2 is correct.
The purchases account used in the periodic inventory system is an expense account. Inventory is essentially expensed at point of purchase.

questiontext.text: A business that uses the perpetual inventory system has a period total of R6500.00 for the cost of sales column in its debtors journal. How would this be entered into the general ledger?

generalfeedback.text: Option 1 is correct. The contra-account for cost of sales is trading inventory. The cost of sales column will be debited as the expense increases and the trading inventory account will be credited as inventory stocks are depleted.

answer.text: Debit cost of sales R6 500.00; credit trading inventory R6 500.00.
Credit cost of sales R6 500.00; debit trading inventory R6 500.00.
Debit cost of sales R5 000.00; debit input VAT R700.00; credit trading inventory R6 500.00.
Credit cost of sales R5 000.00; debit input VAT R700.00; debit trading inventory R6 500.00.

questiontext.text: Which of the following accounts are liabilites?

generalfeedback.text:
Options 1 and 2 is correct.

Money owing at year end (accrued expenses) or income received before it is earned, is a liability.

answer.text: Accrued income (interest on a fixed deposit).

questiontext.text: Which of the following is<u> not</u> an example of an account created at year end to apply the accrual concept?

generalfeedback.text:
Option 4 is correct.

The depreciation account is a year end adjustment to adjust the cost price of a non-current asset downwards to its fair value. It is not an account born from the accrual concept.

feedback.text: This is a year end adjustment but not based on the accrual concept.

questiontext.text: What type of account is the accrued income account?

generalfeedback.text: Option 3 is correct.The accrued income is earned even though not received and is thus an asset (current).

questiontext.text: Interest owing on a fixed deposit account would give rise to which of the following year end adjustment accounts?

generalfeedback.text:
Option 3 is correct.

The interest for the month from the fixed deposit is accrued to you at month end so an accrued income account is created.

questiontext.text: Rental received would give rise to which of the following year end adjustment accounts?

generalfeedback.text:
Option 4 is correct.

Rental is received a month in advance and so gives rise to a liability and an adjustment for income received in advance must be created.

questiontext.text: An employee, Joe, works a 35 hour week. He gets paid R50 per hour normal time. If Mr Smith earns a gross wage of R1975 for the week, how many hours of overtime did he work? (Overtime is paid at time and a half).

generalfeedback.text:
Option 3 is correct.
R1975-(R50 x 35)=R225 extra pay for the week over the normal weekly wage. R225/(R50x 1.5)=3
Therefore Joe worked 3 hours of overtime in that week.

questiontext.text: If an employee earns a gross wage of R1200 for the week, how much would be deducted from the employee for UIF contributions and how would be contributed by the employer?

generalfeedback.text:
Option 4 is correct.
A total of 2% of the gross wage must be paid to the UIF, 1% is deducted from the employee and 1% is contributed by the employer. 1% of R1200= R12. Thus both the employee and employer owe the UIF R12.

answer.text: R24 deducted from employee; R0 contributed by the employer.
R24 deducted from employee; R0 contributed by the employer.
R0 deducted from employee; R24 contributed by the employer.
R12 deducted from employee; R0 contributed by the employer.
R12 deducted from employee; R12 contributed by the employer.

questiontext.text:
Complete the below Accounting Equation.

Owner's Equity = Assets - _______

generalfeedback.text:
The accounting equation is:

Owner's Equity = Assets-Liabilities

questiontext.text: An owner deposits R50,000 into the business bank account. This results in which accounting scenario?

generalfeedback.text: A deposit of cash will increase the bank account, therefore increasing assets. As it is the owner who deposits the cash, the capital account will also increase, therefore increasing owner's equity.

questiontext.text: Which of the following incorporate the duties of the executor?

generalfeedback.text:
Options 2,3 and 4 are correct.

The executor deals with the adminstration of the estate, and liaises with the Master of the Court who plays the supervisory role.

answer.text: Play a supervisory role in the administration of the etstate.
Distribute the balance of the estate to the entitled beneficiaries.
Deal with all the administration surrounding the estate.
Liaise with the Master of the court.

questiontext.text: Which of the following are not included in the estate of the insolvent?

generalfeedback.text:
Options 1 and 2 are correct.

Monies received for work done after sequestration and pension monies are not included in the assets available for sequestration. Property and furniture would be included as these can be sold to raise cash to pay the creditors.

answer.text: Money received for work done after sequestration.

questiontext.text: For sequestration to apply the debtor must prove...?

generalfeedback.text:
Options 2 and 3 are correct.

The debtor must prove that:
  • His estate is insolvent.
  • That there is enough cash to pay creditors in part or full as well as enough to cover sequestration costs.
  • That he has notified creditors of his intentions to apply for sequestration.

answer.text: He has no money or assets to pay any creditors.
That he has notified creditors of his intention to apply for sequestration.
All of the above must apply.

questiontext.text: How would a concession granted by a creditor reducing the amount owed from R200 000 to R150 000 impact the current financial year assesed loss?

generalfeedback.text:
Option 2 is correct.

The assessed loss would be reduced by R50 000.

answer.text: reduce assessed loss by the concession amount
increase assessed loss by the concession amount

questiontext.text: The escape clause that allows a taxpayer to prevent a loss from being ring-fenced is called:

generalfeedback.text:
Option 2 is correct.

The facts and circumstances test is the escape clause that the taxpayer can use to avoid the ring-fecing of a loss.

questiontext.text:
A person is no longer able to rely on the facts and circumstances test (the
escape clause) where losses from a suspect trade (but excluding farming)have been incurred in........

generalfeedback.text:
Option 3 is correct.

A person is no longer able to rely on the facts and circumstances test (the
escape clause) where losses from a suspect trade (but excluding farming) have  been incurred in six out of ten years.

questiontext.text: Ring fencing can only be applied where the following conditions are met:

generalfeedback.text:
Option 4 is correct.

Ring-fencing can only be applied if the taxpayer is a natural person whose taxable income (before the deduction of any assessed losses) is subject to the maximum marginal rate of tax and he/she either had an assessed loss in at least three out of the last five tax years.

answer.text: The taxable income (before the deduction of any assessed losses) is subject to the maximum marginal rate of tax.
There is an assessed loss in at least three out of the last five tax years

questiontext.text: If losses are made in the 2005, 2006 and 2008 tax years, but a profit is made in the 2007 tax year, the potential ring-fencing is

generalfeedback.text:
Option 2 is correct.

A profit made in a particular tax year will also delay the potential ring-fencing of losses from that specific trade in terms of the three-out-of-five year rule.

questiontext.text: Where on the financial statments would you find the amount for the account "Allowance of credit losses"?

generalfeedback.text:
Option 3 is correct.

The Notes to the Balance sheet will contain a note for Trade Receivables and any Allowance for Credit Loss will be icluded in the calculation.

answer.text: On the face of the balance sheet under current assets.
On the face of the balance sheet under current liabilities.
In the Notes to the balance sheet for the Trade receivables account.
It won't appear on the balance sheet as the account will be a nil value.

questiontext.text:
The following is an extract from Table (Pty)Ltd at 30 Sept 2011, the last day of the financial year.

Pre-adjustment trial balance:
Statement of financial position section
Debtors Control 150 000 (debit)

Adjustment for 30 Sept 2011:
An allowance must be made for credit losses for 5% of outstanding trade receivables.

In the General Journal below what should be entered at 'A'?

Details                          Debit                  Credit

"A" 	                            7500 	

Allowance for credit losses 		        7500

generalfeedback.text:
Option 2 is correct.

'Allowance for credit losses adjustment' is the contra-account against 'Allowance for credit losses'.

questiontext.text:
At year end it is decided the outstanding balance of a debtor, K Kimbel, must be written off as irrecoverable. The balance is currently R1000.

Which accounts must be debited and credited to reflect write off of debt?

generalfeedback.text:
Option 3 is correct. General journal of X (Pty)Ltd at year end.

Details 	         Debit 	      Credit

Credit losses	           1000

Debtors control (K Kimber)
 		                 1000

Credit losses written off.

answer.text: Dr Debtors Control (K.Kimbel) R1000; Cr Credit losses R1000
Dr Allowance for credit losses R1000; Cr Debtors Control R1000
Dr Credit losses R1000; Cr Debtors Control (K.Kimbel) R1000
Dr Allowance for credit losses adjustment R1000;Cr Allowance for credit losses R1000

questiontext.text:
James is 30 years old. He earned an annual salary of R 250 000 and paid medical aid contributions of R 2 400 per month (his wife and child are both dependants on his medical aid) during the 2012 tax year. In addition his other qualifying medical expenses not covered by medical aid were R 12 000 during the 2012 year of assessment. He had no other deductions.

Calculate his taxable income.

generalfeedback.text:
The limit for the deduction of medical aid contributions is R 720 ( each per month for the main member and the first dependant and an additional R 440 per month for each additional dependant.

Salary: ________________________________________________________R250 000
Less:
Medical aid contributions (R2400 x 12) = R 28 800
Limited to (R720 + R720 + R440) x12 = R 22 560 ____________________(R22 560)

Balance of R6 240 to be added to other medical expenditure below.

Less:
R12 000 + R6 240 = R18 240 less 7.5% x (R250 000 - R22 560) _________ (R1 182)
Taxable income________________________________________________ R226 258

questiontext.text:
A warehouse containing trading stock burns down in fire. The building and all the trading stock are destroyed.

Can the losses be deducted from taxable income?

generalfeedback.text:
Option 3 is correct.

A loss of a fixed asset is not deductible as the fixed asset forms part of the capital of the business.

The trading stock, however, can be deducted to the extent it is not covered by insurance.

answer.text: All the losses caused by the fire can be deducted.
The loss of the building can be deducted.
The loss of the trading stock not covered by insurance can be deducted.
None of the losses caused by the fire can be deducted.

questiontext.text: Where an annuity is paid by an employer to a retired employee, can the annuity payments be deducted from the employee's taxable income?

generalfeedback.text: Option 3 is correct. According to S11(n) states that "the value of the deduction (which the individual employee can deduct from his/her taxable income) is limited to the greater of..."

answer.text: No, it can't be deducted at all.
Yes, but subject to a limit.

questiontext.text: Sally Pringle is a sole proprietor running a kiddies party business. She knows she can deduct some travel expenses and has already deducted her lease payments Which of the following travel expenses can she further deduct?

generalfeedback.text:
Options 1,3 and 4 are correct.

Travel expenses include, but are not limited to, the following common expenses:
• Fuel • Finance charges
• Maintenance • Wear and tear
• Licence • Lease payments
• Insurance • Parking expenses

You may only claim either wear and tear on your motor vehicle or the lease payments paid during the tax year – you cannot claim both.

questiontext.text: For expenditure to be claimed as a deduction which of the following are true?

generalfeedback.text:
Option 2 is correct.

Expenditure must be claimed as a deduction in the year in which it is incurred and cannot be deferred to a subsequent tax year.

answer.text: It can be deferred and claimed in the next tax year.
It must be claimed in the current tax year.
There are no rules pertaining to when the deduction can be claimed.

questiontext.text: A company erects a billboard outside of its premises advertising new products. Can the company deduct the expense of the billboard costs from income?

generalfeedback.text:
Option 1 is correct.

Certain methods of advertising may be of a capital nature and are not deductible.
Advertising structures that create an enduring benefit or are permanent in nature may be regarded as capital in nature and therefore not deductible for tax purposes.

answer.text: No, the expense is not deductible.

questiontext.text:
The Income Tax Act makes provision for the deduction of specific expenses which may not fall within the general deduction formula.

Which of the following do not fall under these specific expenses?

generalfeedback.text:
Options 5 is correct.

Expenses incurred in the connection with income tax are not deductible.

answer.text: Restraint of trade payments paid to a natural person.
The registration or extension of the term of a copyright.
Finance charges incurred on the purchase of a warehouse used in a business.
Leasehold improvement costs paid by the lessee.
Legal expenses in connection with income tax appeals.

questiontext.text:
The accountant of Bigbay (Pty) Ltd, a business engaged in selling furniture, has prepared a list of credit losses at the end of its financial year (31December 2011). This list is as follows:
  1. Bad debt 1: R 2 566 due for goods dispatched on 3 July 2012 in terms of Invoice 200. All attempts to trace the debtor are futile.
  2. Bad debt 2: A loan of furniture to an office worker on promise they will repay the debt. The office worker never returned to work.

Which of the above bad debts can be deductible for tax purposes?

generalfeedback.text:
Option 1 is correct.

As bad debt 1 has already been included in the income of the business the resulting bad debt can be deductible. However bad debt 2 to was not included in the income of the company and therefore cannot be deductible as bad debt.

questiontext.text:
For the 2012 tax year, Mr Plod (aged 40 years) earns the following income:

Salary R 240 000

He contributed R 10 500 to a pension fund.

How much can Mr Plod deduct in repect of contributions to the pension fund
in terms of s11(k)?

generalfeedback.text:
Option 3 is correct.

Retirement funding employment:
Salary R 240 000

Her deduction would be limited to the greater of:
(i) R 1750
(ii) 7.5 % x R 240 000 = R 18 000

Therefore the S11 (k) pension fund deduction would be limited to R 18 000.

questiontext.text:
A restuarant owner had a burst pipe under the sink which resulted in water damage to his wooden kitchen floor which collapsed as a result. He had the floor replaced with a new wood floor.

Would the cost of this flooring be deductible in terms of capital allowances s11(d)?

generalfeedback.text:
Option 1 is correct.

Repairs incurred during the year of assessment may be allowed as a deduction.

Repairs must be in respect of:
• Property occupied for the purpose of trade or in respect of which income is receivable.
• Treatment against attack by beetles of any timber forming part of such property.
• Machinery, implements, utensils and other articles employed for purposes of trade.

The costs of improvements or additions to property are not deductible because such expenditure is of a capital nature and will result in an increase in income - earning capacity.

answer.text: Yes, this is a repair that will restore the cost of his asset back to its original state.
No, this is a repair that will increase his earning capactiy and thus capital by nature.
No, repairs and maintenance are not deductible allowances.

questiontext.text: How many houses of a housing development need to be let before the developer will be be able to claim a deduction according to the s13ter allowance?

generalfeedback.text:
Option 3 is correct.

The allowance will be granted in the year that at least 5 units are let. In addition, where a unit is no longer utilised as required by the section a recoupment must be added to gross income in the year that this occurs.

questiontext.text:
Jane is a 42 year old taxpayer who has a child with a disability. She had a taxable income of R 124 000 during the current year of assessment and had the following qualifying medicalexpenses:
• Contributions to a medical fund R 15 000 (Liza and her child are members)
• Medical expenses not paid for by the medical aid R 5 000.

How much of Jane's medical expenses will be an allowable deduction?

generalfeedback.text:
Option 4 is correct.

As Jane has a child with a disability she is allowed to claim all of her medical expenses as an allowable deduction.

questiontext.text: Where a company gives partial recognition to interdepartmental services by determining which department provides the most interdepartment services and apportioning those first amongst other departments, this company will be using which of the following methods to assign service department costs?

generalfeedback.text:
Option 3 is correct.

The step method methodically assigns interdepartmental costs amongst other departments starting with the department that provides the most interdepartmental services and ending with the least.

questiontext.text: Which of the following are ability tests used in South Africa? (Choose at least one answer)

generalfeedback.text: Rorschach Test (Options 2)  is a projective technique used for personality tests, and  Mental Alertness Scale of the NIPR (option 4) is an intelligence test.

questiontext.text: assess the underlying psychological constructs which determine how individuals will behaviourally respond to social situations.

generalfeedback.text: Personality tests assess the underlying psychological constructs which determine how individuals will behaviourally respond to social situations.

questiontext.text: Which of the following are types of semi-structured interviews? (Choose at least one answer)

generalfeedback.text: Personality interviews (option 4) is not a type of semi-structured interview.

questiontext.text: A writing skills test for editors is an example of a

generalfeedback.text: A writing skills test for editors is an example of a performance test.

questiontext.text: . . . are characterised by careful, systematic planning of the interview and exclusive use of technically skilled interviewers.

generalfeedback.text: Structured interviews are characterised by careful, systematic planning of the interview and exclusive use of technically skilled interviewers.

questiontext.text: During the selection process, two types of costs must be taken into account.  They are . . .

generalfeedback.text: During the selection process, two types of costs must be taken into account.  They are cost of filling a post and potential costs.

answer.text: Cost of terminating service and cost of selecting another employee
Cost of filling a post and potential costs
Cost of low productivity and labour turnover.

questiontext.text: The following internal environment factors of the organisation can influence the selection decision

generalfeedback.text: Size, nature, social pressure and government regulations are internal environment factors of the organisation that can influence the selection decision.

answer.text: Size, nature, social pressure of the organisation and number of candidates for a certain job
Size, nature of labour and social pressure.
Trade unions, labour markets and government regulations.
Size, nature, social pressure and government regulations

questiontext.text:
Which of the following accounts are NOT credited when posting from the salaries register

to the general ledger accounts?

generalfeedback.text: The ‘net salary’ total is the same amount credited to ‘Creditors for salaries’

questiontext.text: The following type of remuneration must not be considered when calculating UIF remuneration.

generalfeedback.text: Table on page 54: Commission is excluded when calculating UIF remuneration

questiontext.text: In the tax year 2013/2014, the net tax due for a person 68 years old, with an annual taxable income of R 170 000 will equal to….
‘Balance of remuneration’ is the same as ….

generalfeedback.text: Certain deductions from gross income are allowed to arrive at the ‘balance of remuneration’

questiontext.text: The payment of wages and salaries represent an expense to a business and is entered into…….

generalfeedback.text: All payments to employees and different funds are entered from the salaries register into the cashbook payments journal and then posted to the respective accounts.

questiontext.text: Salaried employees are paid during month and enterprises usually pay out salaries to employees by using different methods. Which method among the following is not used?

generalfeedback.text: Salaries are usually paid out by means of a salary cheque, EFT or magnetic tape transfer, and often involve statutory deductions such as UIF, SDL & PAYE as well as fringe benefits.

questiontext.text: Employer’s contributions to SARS are calculated by always using the following percentage of gross salaries.

generalfeedback.text: UIF must be calculated from each employee’s UIF remuneration and SDL must be calculated from each employee’s PAYE/SDL remuneration. Gross salary sometimes includes commission ( affects UIF) as well as pension contributions( which affects SDL).

answer.text: Not necessarily any one of the above.

questiontext.text: The total/balance of salaries/ wages amount that must be paid to SARS by the 7th following month is entered into the form called………

generalfeedback.text: The EMP 201 is usually submitted on or before the 7th day of the following month.

questiontext.text: A business will be exempt from the payment of the SDL where the leviable amount of the employer does not exceed R…………………..per annum

generalfeedback.text: Integration task 4.1, no. 2. – study guide page 17.

questiontext.text: The acronym for ‘total cost to company’ approach is…..

generalfeedback.text: Integration task 4.2, study guide page 18 – Most companies are moving towards a ‘Total/Balance cost to company approach (also known as the total/balance employment cost or TEC approach)

questiontext.text: The maximum UIF remuneration threshold is presently R ……….

generalfeedback.text: The threshold was R14 872 with effect from 1 October 2012 (previously this was R12 478 with effect from 1 October 2007).

questiontext.text: Which of the following sampling methods used by auditors would ensure that each item in the population has an equal chance of being selected?

generalfeedback.text:
Options 1 and 3 are correct.

Using the random selection or MUS method would ensure all items in a populationhave an equal chance of selection.

questiontext.text: The risk an auditor will not identify material misstatements in the financial statements is referred to as:

generalfeedback.text:
Option 4 is correct.

Detection risk is the risk that the auditor will not detect material misstatements in the financial statements.

questiontext.text: The record detailing all the important details of an asset is called an asset _______.

generalfeedback.text: The record detailing all the important details of an asset is called an asset register.

questiontext.text: A rectangles shorter side is 5cm and its longer side measures 10cm. What is the perimeter of the rectangle?

generalfeedback.text: Option 3 is correct. P=2(5) + 2(10)=30

questiontext.text: The length of leg A of a right triangle is 12m and the length of leg B is 6m. What is the length of the hypotenuse?

generalfeedback.text:
Option 1 is correct.
c2 = 122 + 62
square root of 180 = 13.42m

questiontext.text:
What is the average grade of the accounting test written if the results of the class were as follows?

5 students scored 80%.

5 students scored 50%.

2 students scored 35%.

generalfeedback.text:
Option 3 is correct.

The class average was calculated as follows:

(5 x 80%)+(5 x 50%)+(2 x 35%) = 720

720÷12= 60%

questiontext.text: <font size=2>A country has a comparative advantage when it can ------------. </font>

generalfeedback.text:
Option 3 is correct.

A country has a comparative advantage when it can produce a product at a lower opportunity cost than can another country.

answer.text: produce more of a product than can another country
produce a product at a lower dollar cost than can another country
produce a product at a lower opportunity cost than can another country
produce a better product, regardless of price, than can another country

questiontext.text: <font size=2>Alpha can produce either 10 apples or 3 oranges. Beta can produce either 12 apples or 3 oranges.</font>

generalfeedback.text:
Option 3 is correct.

Absolute advantage is achieved where a country can produce more of a particular good than another country. Beta produces 12 apples were Alpha only produces 10.

answer.text: Alpha has an absolute advantage in the production of apples.
Alpha has an absolute advantage in the production of oranges.
Beta has an absolute advantage in the production of apples.
Beta has a comparative advantage in the production of oranges.

questiontext.text:
The table below shows the maximum output of widgets and gadgets for two countries: Utopia and Nirvana. Which of the following is correct?

Widgets Gadgets
Utopia 1000 1000
Nirvana 500 250

generalfeedback.text:
Option 4 is correct.

Utopias opportunity cost for either good is 1.

Nirvanas opportunity cost of widgets is 1/2.

Nirvanas opportunity cost of gadgets is 2.

Since 1/2 <2 then Nirvana has a comparative advantage in widgets.

answer.text: Nirvana has an absolute advantage in both goods.
Nirvana has a comparative advantage in both goods.
Utopia has a comparative advantage in both goods.
Nirvana has a comparative advantage in widgets.
Nirvana has a comparative advantage in gadgets.

questiontext.text:
Refer to the table below. Which of the following statements is correct?

Cakes Pies
George 5 10
Ricky 4 6

generalfeedback.text:
Option 2 is correct.

George can produce more pies per hour than Ricky, thus George has an absolute advantage in pies. George also has to give up less cakes for each pie than Ricky. Thus, George also has a comparative advantage.

answer.text: Ricky has the comparative advantage in pies.
George has the absolute advantage in pies.
George has the absolute and comparative advantage in pies.
George has a comparative advantage but not an absolute advantage in pies.
Ricky has an absolute advantage but not a comparative advantage in pies.

questiontext.text: Why do people specialize and trade?

generalfeedback.text:
Option is 1 correct.

Since people have different comparative advantages, more can be produced and consumed through specialization and trading in markets.

answer.text: Because each person can consume more than they produce by specializing and trading.
Because most people are not self sufficient.
Because most people are good at producing only one thing.
Because people have to have jobs in order to survive.

questiontext.text: If a country wants to trade a product with another country, it must have a/an ----------- in the production of that product.

generalfeedback.text:
Option 4 is correct.

If a country wants to trade a product with another country, it must have a/an comparative advantage in the production of that product.

questiontext.text: Which of the following accounts make up the final accounts of the close corporation?

generalfeedback.text:
Options 1,2 and 3 are correct.

All entities other than a sole trader, will have an additional account to facilitate distribtions amongst equity partners- the appropriation account.

questiontext.text: If using the perpetual inventory method which of the following journals would contain a cost of sales column in its structure?

generalfeedback.text: Options 1,2 and 3 are correct.

feedback.text: The creditors journal is used to record credit purchases and not credit sales.

questiontext.text: In the perpetual inventory system the contra-account of the cost of sales account is always which account?

generalfeedback.text: Option 2 is correct.

questiontext.text: The note in the T-account that refers to the name of the account on the “other” side of the entry is the cross-reference or -------.

generalfeedback.text: Contra means “against”, so this is the entry in another account that balances out the entry in the original account.

questiontext.text:
Complete the accounting equation by inserting the word below.

Owners Equity = Assets - _______

generalfeedback.text: The accounting equation is Owner's Equity= Assets - Liabilities. The nature of the equation is such that it must always balance.

feedback.text: Please note this is spelt liabilities.

questiontext.text:
Fill in the missing phrase.

A formal term for the wealth of the owner in a business is _______ ______.

generalfeedback.text: Owner's equity refers to the value of the owners share in the business, and can be calculated by subtracting liabilities from assets.

feedback.text: Please remember to use the apostrophe to indicate ownership: Owner's equity

questiontext.text: Section ______ of the Income Tax Act details how one is to deal with assessed loss.

generalfeedback.text: Section 20 of the Income Tax Act details how one is to deal with assessed loss.

questiontext.text: Fill in the missing word:  In the ………. interview, the interviewer determines the course that the interview will follow as each question is asked

generalfeedback.text: In the structured interview, the interviewer determines the course that the interview will follow as each question is asked

questiontext.text: Fill in the missing word:  ………. refers to the potential to acquire certain skills through training and experience.

generalfeedback.text: Aptitude refers to the potential to acquire certain skills through training and experience

questiontext.text:
Tanja disposed of her primary residence on 15 January 2013. The proceeds on this sale were

R3 500 000 and the base cost was R800 000.

The capital gain = R _________

generalfeedback.text: R3 500 000 less R2 000 000(Primary residence exclusion) less R800 000 = R700 000

questiontext.text:
Tanja also disposed of property owned by her in the USA on 1 December 2012 for the rand value of R3 500 000 – her base cost on this property was R2 300 000. Tanja was required to pay an equivalent of R52 000 USA taxes on this disposal.

The capital gain = R __________

Tanja has the following assets and liabilities as at 28 February 2013: Property, R4 000 000; Beach cottage, R800 000; Mortgage bond on the property, R2 250 000; Cash in bank, R 45 000; Car loan, R95 000; Personal effects, R 40 000, Furniture and fittings, R 80 000. The statement of assets and liabilities will show total liabilities to equal R ________

generalfeedback.text: R2 345 000 = Mortgage bond of R2 250 000 plus Car loan of R95 000.

questiontext.text: A ______angle is a 90 degree angle.

generalfeedback.text: A right angle is a 90 degree angle.

questiontext.text: The number of square units needed to cover a given surface is known as the _______ area.

generalfeedback.text: The number of square units needed to cover a given surface is known as the surface area.

questiontext.text: The _______ of a set numbers is taking the total sum and dividing it by the actual number of numbers in the set.

generalfeedback.text: The average of a set numbers is taking the total sum and dividing it by the actual number of numbers in the set.

questiontext.text: Fill in the missing word(s). In the perpetual inventory system the contra-account of the cost of sales account is the -------account?

generalfeedback.text: In the perpetual inventory system the contra-account of the cost of sales account is the trading inventory account.

questiontext.text:
Fill in the missing word.

The debit side of a T-account is on the ------ side.

generalfeedback.text: The debit side of the T-account is on the left and the credit side is on the right.

feedback.text: Correct, well done. Debit is a Latin meaning "left".

questiontext.text:
Complete the phrase below by supply the missing word.

Total debits must always equal total -----.

generalfeedback.text: The system of bookkeeping specifies that for every debit entry there must be a corresponding credit entry. Thus debits will always equal credits.

questiontext.text: Goods are delivered to a company where the receiving clerk checks them and verbally accepts delivery. This is effective control enough as the receiving clerk has been with the company for 20 years.

generalfeedback.text: This is false. A goods received note must be made out or a delivery note signed and goods delivered checked against the purchase order. Even though the delivery clerk in a long-term employee, no risk must be taken when it comes to fraud or theft.

questiontext.text: A cheques written out for payment of supplys delivered must be sugned by two authorised signatories for effective control.

generalfeedback.text: This is true. If this is not possible then there must be a limit up to which one signatory can sign a check. Above this limit there must be two signatories.

generalfeedback.text: This is true. A good example would be between payroll costs and the number of employees.

questiontext.text: The cost driver rate is calculated as the activity cost divided by the cost driver volume.

generalfeedback.text: This is true. The cost driver rate is calculated as the activity cost divided by the cost driver volume.

questiontext.text: A traditional costing system is more accurate when it comes to assigning overhead costs than an activities based costing system.

generalfeedback.text: This is false. A traditional costing system is less accurate when it comes to assigning overhead costs than an activities based costing system.

questiontext.text: A company producing a diverse product range would be best suited to an activity based costing system.

generalfeedback.text: This is true. A diverse product range consumes resources in different proportions and thus an acitivity based costing system will better suit as it identifies a greater variety of cost drivers.

questiontext.text: Activity based costing uses historical data to approximate product costs and thus could introduce and inappropriate level of variability.

generalfeedback.text:
This is true.

Using historical information and not adapting it to production changes could lead to inappropriate levels of variability.

questiontext.text: Activity based costing can confuse the understanding of overheads and how they apply to products made.

generalfeedback.text:
This is false.

Activity based costing improves understanding of overheads and how they apply to products made.

questiontext.text: Direct costs are calculated in the same way for both traditional costing systems and activity-based costing systems.

generalfeedback.text:
This is true.

The treatment of indirect costs is where the difference lies between traditional costing systems and activity-based costing systems.

questiontext.text: Activity based costing systems assists in reducing product cost distortion.

generalfeedback.text:
This is true.

This acheived by using cost drivers to assign overheads to activities.

questiontext.text: Under activity based costing systems support centre costs are merged with production centre costs.

generalfeedback.text:
This is false.

Support centre costs are separated from production centre costs.

questiontext.text: Activity-based costing allocates overheads to each major activity rather than departments.

generalfeedback.text:
This is true.

ABC is a costing model that assigns manufacturing overheads to different products produced by a manufacturing entity.

questiontext.text: Activity-based costing is more suited to organisations with low competition levels.

generalfeedback.text:
This is false.

Activity-based costing is more suited to organisations with high competition levels.

questiontext.text: The use of activity-based costing improves the understanding of overheads in the business.

generalfeedback.text:
This is true.

Using activity-based costing improves the understanding of overheads in the business.

questiontext.text: By using activity-based costing management can better identify activities of non-value and address them.

generalfeedback.text:
This is true.

Using activity-based costing the business is closely analysing all activities and thus in the process can identify wasteful and non-value added activities.

questiontext.text: An advantage of activity-based costing system is that it is an easy and quick system to set up and maintain.

generalfeedback.text:
This is false.

Activity-based costing can be an expensive system to buy, set up and maintain due to the time-consuming nature of data collection and costing of all activities.

questiontext.text: The number of machine hours is a cost driver related to the activity of machining.

generalfeedback.text:
This is true.

An cost driver must explain the overhead costs in each activity cost pool, be easily measurable and be related with the product.

questiontext.text: A traditional costing system more accurately approximates product costs to cost objects than an activity-based system.

generalfeedback.text:
This is false.

A traditional system less accurately approximates product costs as it uses cost drivers with no cause-and-effect relationships to assign support costs to cost objects.

questiontext.text: An activity-based system has a greater number and variety of cost centres than a traditional cost system.

generalfeedback.text:
This is true.

An ABC system uses both unit-based and non-unit-based activity drivers while the traditional system uses only unit-based drivers.

questiontext.text: Non-unit-based drivers are directly related to the level of production.

generalfeedback.text:
This is false.

Unit-based drivers are directly related to the level of production while non-unit based drivers are not.

questiontext.text: An asset cannot be written off mid-way through a financial year as the carrying value of the asset cannot be calculated until year end.

generalfeedback.text:
This is false.

An additional depreciation adjustment will be at the time of disposal to cover the period from the previous year end to the date of disposal mid year.

questiontext.text: The difference between the disposal of current and non-current assets is that depreciation needs to be taken into account in the case of disposal of non-current assets.

generalfeedback.text:
This is true.

The carrying value of the non-current asset needs to be taken into account when calculating the profit of a non-current asset. This is no the case for current assets as they are not depreciated at all.

questiontext.text: Carrying value = selling price less accumulated depreciation

generalfeedback.text:
This is false.

Carrying value = INITIAL COST PRICE less accumulated depreciation

Carrying value is what the non-current asset is currently worth to the owner.

questiontext.text: Gains and losses on re-measuring available-for-sale financial assets are included in the 'other comprehensive income' section of the statement of comprehensive income.

generalfeedback.text: This is true.

questiontext.text: Any changes to the equity of the company will be listed on the 'Statement of changes in equity'.

generalfeedback.text:
This is true.
The Statement of changes in equity shows the opening balances, movements and closing balances for each of the equity accounts listed in the statement of financial position.

questiontext.text: Any transfer to and from reserves will be depicted on the statement of changes in equity for the year ended.

generalfeedback.text:
This is true.
Changes in reserves will increase or decrease the the equity of the company and this needs to be represented in the financials of the company.

questiontext.text: On the perpetual system when inventory is sold the inventory account is debited and the expense cost of sales is credited.

generalfeedback.text: When goods are sold under the perpetual system the cost of sales figure is calculated and is debited to cost of sales account(increasing the expense) and credited to the inventory account (decreasing the asset).

questiontext.text: The contra-account of the cost of sales is always sales.

generalfeedback.text: The contra-account of cost of sales is trading inventory.

questiontext.text: A stock take performed under the perpetual trading system would highlight any stock losses for the year.
The accrual concept is concerned with when actual income is received as opposed to when it is earned.

generalfeedback.text: This is false.The accrual concept is concerned with when actual income is earned as opposed to when it is received.

questiontext.text:
ABC Pty Ltd has a 31 December 2011 year end. At year end the January salary (R6000) for an employee Billy Smith had already been paid.
After the year end adjustments have been performed the income statement at year end would reflect a decrease in expenses of R6000 (wages and salaries) and the statement of financial position would reflect an increase in assets of R6000(Trade receivables-Prepaid expenses).

generalfeedback.text:
This is true.

Prepaid expenses gives rise to an asset on the statement of financial position.

questiontext.text:
ABC Pty Ltd has a 31 December 2011 year end. At year end the January rental (R4000) from a tenant in one of the companies warehouse is paid.
After year end adjustments have been processed the income statement at year end would reflect a decrease in income of R4000 (rental income) and the statement of financial position would reflect an increase in assets of R4000(trade receivables-income received in advance).

generalfeedback.text:
This is false.

Income received in advance gives rise to a liability on the statement of financial position.

questiontext.text: Wages usually involve all statutory deductions.

generalfeedback.text: This is false. Wages do not usually involve all statutory deductions other than UIF, SDL and PAYE.

questiontext.text: The Master of the Court will issue a letter of executorship to the executor, whereafter the executor can administer the estate of the deceased.

generalfeedback.text: This is true.

questiontext.text: An insolvent estate is one where the assets exceed liabilities.

generalfeedback.text: This is false. An insolvent estate is one where the liabilities exceed assets.

questiontext.text: Sequestration by the High Court ensures protection of the insolvent and a fair distribution of assets can be made to the creditors.

generalfeedback.text: This is true.

questiontext.text: When a taxpayer incurs an assessed loss during a year of assessment, it may be utilised to reduce taxable income earned during the same or a future year of assessment.

generalfeedback.text: This is true.

questiontext.text: The list of suspect trades are in essence activities that will normally be considered as a hobby (for example gambling and sport) but are carried out by the taxpayer as part of a professional trade.

generalfeedback.text: This is true.

questiontext.text: Before a company can carry forward its assessed loss from the immediately preceding year of assessment, it must have carried on a trade during the current year of assessment. If it fails to do so, it will forfeit the right to carry forward its balance of assessed loss

generalfeedback.text: This is true.

questiontext.text: Once a loss is ring-fenced it is permanently ring-fenced and can only be set off against future income arising from this trade.

generalfeedback.text: This is true.

questiontext.text: Suspect trades are not ring fenced according to the 6 out of 10 year generated losses rule.

generalfeedback.text:
This is false.

Suspect trades are ring fenced according to the 6 out of 10 year generated losses rule.

questiontext.text:
Assessed losses carried forward from a prior tax year may be set off against
trade income received.

generalfeedback.text: This is true.

questiontext.text: A company is only entitled to set off its assessed loss from the previous year against its taxable income in the current year, if the taxpayer has carried on a trade during the current year and has derived income from that trade.

generalfeedback.text:
This is true.

A company must have carried on a trade in the next year and derived an income from said trade in order to be allowed  to set off the assessed loss from the prior year.

questiontext.text: A natural person must have carried on a trade in the following year in order to set off the assessed loss from the prior year.

generalfeedback.text:
This is false.

In terms of S20(2A)  natural persons and trusts that may set an assessed loss off against non-trade income. The natural person does not need tohave carried on trading in the current year in order to set off the assesed loss.

questiontext.text: An insolvent estate, filing a tax return for the year ended 31 December 2013, may not include an assessed loss incurred prior to insolvency.

generalfeedback.text: This is false.

questiontext.text: An assessed loss resulting from trade carried on outside of the Republic can only be set off against income earned from other foreign trades.

generalfeedback.text: This is true.

questiontext.text: Ring-fencing of assessed losses (s20A) only applies to companies.

generalfeedback.text:
This is false.

Ring-fencing of assessed losses (s20A) only applies to natural persons.

questiontext.text: Where a loss arises from a trade that falls under the s20A(2)(b) suspect list, the taxpayer's loss is automatically ring-fenced.

generalfeedback.text:
This is false.

Where a taxpayer can prove that he can derive a reasonable taxable income from that particular trade within a reasonable time period, the ring-fencing of the loss can be avoided.

questiontext.text: Farming or animal breeding is on the suspect list unless the farmer or breeder can proof he does so on a full-time basis.

generalfeedback.text: This is true.

questiontext.text: Where an amount has been distributed to a person by a pension or provident fund and is included in that person’s gross income, the balance of assessed loss may not be set off against such amount.

generalfeedback.text: This is true.

questiontext.text: The 'allowance for credit losses' is a negative asset.

generalfeedback.text:
This is true.

The provision decreases the potential of inflow of cash. It is the negative asset to the debtors control account.

questiontext.text: The 'allowance for credit losses adjustment' account would be treated as an income account where an there is a decrease in allowances for credit losses.

generalfeedback.text:
This is true.

The allowances for credit losses will be credited by the adjustment amount and written off to profit and loss as income.

questiontext.text: Any type of adjustment can be done at year end as long as it is material to the interpretation of the financial statements by stakeholders.

generalfeedback.text: This is true.

questiontext.text:
For an expense to qualify for deduction in terms of the general deduction the
taxpayer must be carrying on a trade and the taxpayer must, in carrying on that trade, derive income.

generalfeedback.text:
This is true.

‘Trade’ is defined in the Income Tax Act and includes 'every profession, trade, business, employment, calling, occupation or venture, including the letting of any property and the use of, or the grant of permission to use any patent, or any design or any trade mark, or any copyright, or any other property which is of a similar nature.'

questiontext.text: An expense claim as a decudtion will be forfeited if not claimed in the year in which it is incurred.

generalfeedback.text:
This is true.

Expenditure must be claimed as a deduction in the year in which it is incurred – it cannot be deducted in any subsequent years and will be forfeited if not claimed in the year in which it is incurred.

questiontext.text: Susie runs a cake business from home. She delivers her cakes to clients all over Johannesburg. She cannot deduct the delivery expenses incurred as the are not regarded as business travel.

generalfeedback.text:
This is false.

If your home is your office then travelling from your home to clients is regarded as business travel and may be these travel expebses may be deducted from your income.

questiontext.text: Donations to public benefit organisations are allowed as a deduction from taxable income (subject to a limit) in order to encourage people to donate to worthy causes and promote social welfare.

generalfeedback.text:
This is true.

PBO's organisations include welfare companies, health care, education and development amongst others. By aloowing for a tax deduction when donations are made to these organisations makes donating all the more worthwhile.

questiontext.text: Repairs and maintenance to your house (as long as they do not add value to your house) can be deducted from taxable income.

generalfeedback.text:
This is false.

S23(a) prohibits the deduction of the cost of maintenance of the taxpayer, his family or his establishment (home). S23(b) prohibits the deduction of any private or domestic expenditure.

questiontext.text: Capital receipts and accrual are excluded from gross income and equally capital expenses are not allowable as deductions apart from those specific capital allowances granted.

generalfeedback.text: This is true.

questiontext.text: A capital allowance of the value of an asset over its expected lifetime is deductible, if the value of the asset has diminished due to wear and tear.

generalfeedback.text:
This is true.

Although the general deductions formula specifically excludes expenditure of a capital nature, there are sections in the Act which allow the deduction of capital allowances. Capital allowances are the write off of the cost of an asset over a period of years.

questiontext.text: A farmer can deduct in full the cost of farming equipment bought to use on his farm in the first year of its use.

generalfeedback.text:
This is false.

A S12B allowance is claimable on farming plant and equipment but is deductible over three years on the following basis:

Year 1: 50 % of the cost
Year 2: 30 % of the cost
Year 3: 20 % of the cost

questiontext.text: An audit plan must be put in place to ensure proper planning procedures.

generalfeedback.text:
This is true.

The audit plan will include the nature, timing and extent of audit procedures to obtain sufficient appropriate audit evidence to reduce audit risk to an acceptably low level.

questiontext.text: An internal audit report must adhere to the formal reporting requirements.

generalfeedback.text:
This is false.

Internal audit reports are produced for managers and directors only and are unlikely to be shared with third parties. No formal reuqirements need to be adhered too.

questiontext.text: ‘The government may stipulate regulations that can influence the selection decisions of organisations’ is an internal factor that will influence the selection decision.

generalfeedback.text: Feedback:  The above statement is False.   ‘The government may stipulate regulations that can influence the selection decisions of organisations’ is an external (not internal) factor that will influence the selection decision.

questiontext.text: A preliminary interview is long and detailed since the purpose of this interview is to find out as much information as possible about the applicant’s qualifications and suitability for the position.

generalfeedback.text: The above statement is False.  A preliminary interview is short and concise since the purpose of this interview is to pre-select and eliminate applicants who are not qualified for the position.

questiontext.text: One of the purposes of application forms is that they offer sources for reference checks.

generalfeedback.text: The above statement is True.  One of the purposes of application forms is that they offer sources for reference checks.

questiontext.text: A predictor is a selection instrument such as an interview, test, or application blank that assists an organisation in making selection decisions.

generalfeedback.text: The above statement is True.  A predictor is a selection instrument such as an interview, test, or application blank that assists an organisation in making selection decisions.

questiontext.text: Selection decisions require one to know how knowledge, skills and abilities can be assessed, making use of predictors in selection very important.

generalfeedback.text: The above statement is True.  Selection decisions require one to know how knowledge, skills and abilities can be assessed, making use of predictors in selection very important

questiontext.text: An aptitude test gives an indication of general intelligence by means of a single score

feedback.text: The above statement is False.  An intelligence (not a aptitude) test gives an indication of general intelligence by means of a single score.

questiontext.text: The assessment centre enables the organisation to formulate decisions with regard to how candidates function in a group situation.

generalfeedback.text: The above statement is True.  The assessment centre does enable the organisation to formulate decisions with regard to how candidates function in a group situation.

questiontext.text: In a semi-structured interview all questions are compiled in advance.

generalfeedback.text: The above statement is False.  In a semi-structured interview only the most important questions are compiled in advance.

questiontext.text: ‘Salaries registers’ and ‘Wages registers’ serve the same purpose as a ‘Salaries journals and ‘Wages journals’

generalfeedback.text: The totals of the salaries register at the end of the month and totals of the wages register at the end of the period are posted (debited) to ‘salaries expense account’ and ‘wages expense account’ and credited to the rest of the contra accounts.

questiontext.text: The SDL contributions & UIF contributions accounts are liability accounts whereas the EMP 201 and the VAT 201 accounts are expense accounts.

generalfeedback.text: The contributions accounts are expenses to the employer while the EMP 201 and VAT 201 are control accounts and are classified as liabilities.

questiontext.text: The rebate allowed for an individual over 75 years old is R18 830.

generalfeedback.text: Rebate for the individual over 75 = R12 080 + R6 750 + R2 250 = R21 080

questiontext.text: A tax rebate is the amount refunded to a taxpayer because he/she was over- taxed in the previous tax year.

generalfeedback.text: A tax rebate is a basic amount by which the tax liability of the individual is reduced.

questiontext.text: When completing the “investment income section of a tax return,’ local interest income’, ‘foreign interest income’ and ‘foreign dividends’ have to be disclosed separately.

generalfeedback.text: Learning example 5A, page 111.

questiontext.text: Amounts inherited from grand- parents are taxable.

generalfeedback.text: Solution guide, page 39 - Amounts inherited are considered non-taxable

questiontext.text: Using an accounting system offers an enhanced internal control system as checks are automatic all along the accounting cycle.

generalfeedback.text:
This is true.

A manual system needs a lot amore checks and balances in place to ensure internal control.

questiontext.text: SARS does not require a company to keep a 5 year record of all assets after the sale of such assets; it is at the discretion of the company.

generalfeedback.text:
This is false.

It is a prerequisite of SARS that details of all assets be kept for five years after the sale of such assets.

questiontext.text: A country has an absolute advantage whenever it is able to produce more of a given product than another.

generalfeedback.text:
This is true.

Absolute advantage is where a country can produce more of a certain product than another country where the same resources are supplied to both countries.

questiontext.text: The accounting equation is: Owners Equity= Assets + Liabilities

generalfeedback.text: The accounting equation is: Owners Equity= Assets - Liabilities

questiontext.text: A formal term for the wealth of the owner in a business is owner’s equity.

feedback.text: Owners equity refers to the value of the owner’s share in the business, and can be calculated by subtracting liabilities from assets.

questiontext.text: The note in the T-account that refers to the name of the account on the “other” side of the entry is the cross-reference, or contract account.

generalfeedback.text: The corresponding account is the contra-account.

questiontext.text: The debit side of a T-account is on the right.

generalfeedback.text: The debit side relates to the left side of the T-account.

questiontext.text: An owner deposits R50,000 into the business bank account. The change to the accounting equation is an increase in assets and owners equity.

feedback.text: A deposit of cash would increase assets as the bank account is debited and increase owners equity as the capital account is credited.

questiontext.text: When the business acquires an asset, there is a positive change in the owner’s equity of the business.

generalfeedback.text: Correct
